questions.question: A particle starts from rest and accelerates uniformly at $5\,\text{m/s}^2$ for $4$ seconds. What is its final velocity?
questions.explanation: Using the kinematic equation $v = u + at$, where initial velocity $u = 0\,\text{m/s}$, acceleration $a = 5\,\text{m/s}^2$, and time $t = 4\,\text{s}$, we find $v = 0 + 5(4) = 20\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A car traveling at $15\,\text{m/s}$ accelerates uniformly at $3\,\text{m/s}^2$ over a distance of $60\,\text{m}$. What is its final velocity?
questions.explanation: Using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$ with $u = 15\,\text{m/s}$, $a = 3\,\text{m/s}^2$, and $s = 60\,\text{m}$, we have $v^2 = 225 + 2(3)(60) = 225 + 360 = 585$. Thus $v = \sqrt{585} \approx 24.2\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A stone is dropped from rest from a height of $200\,\text{m}$. How long does it take to hit the ground? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Using $h = \frac{1}{2}gt^2$ with $h = 200\,\text{m}$ and $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$, we get $200 = 5t^2 \Rightarrow t^2 = 40 \Rightarrow t = \sqrt{40} \approx 6.32\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A ball is thrown vertically upward with an initial speed of $30\,\text{m/s}$. What is the maximum height reached? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: At maximum height, $v = 0$. Using $v^2 = u^2 - 2gh$, we have $0 = 900 - 20h \Rightarrow h = 45\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched horizontally from a $45\,\text{m}$ high cliff at $12\,\text{m/s}$. What is its horizontal range? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Time to fall: $t = \sqrt{2h/g} = \sqrt{90/10} = \sqrt{9} = 3\,\text{s}$. Horizontal range $= v_x \times t = 12 \times 3 = 36\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A ball is projected at an angle of $53^\circ$ to the horizontal with an initial speed of $50\,\text{m/s}$. What is the vertical component of its initial velocity? (Take $\sin 53^\circ \approx 0.8$)
questions.explanation: $v_y = v\sin\theta = 50 \times 0.8 = 40\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A projectile has initial vertical velocity $v_y = 25\,\text{m/s}$ and horizontal velocity $v_x = 20\,\text{m/s}$. What is its total time of flight? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Time to reach maximum height: $t_{\text{up}} = v_y/g = 25/10 = 2.5\,\text{s}$. Total time of flight $= 2t_{\text{up}} = 2 \times 2.5 = 5\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A boat can move at $8\,\text{m/s}$ in still water. It heads directly perpendicular to a river current flowing at $6\,\text{m/s}$. What is the boat's resultant speed relative to the ground?
questions.explanation: The velocity components are perpendicular, so the resultant speed is $v = \sqrt{8^2 + 6^2} = \sqrt{64 + 36} = \sqrt{100} = 10\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: Car A travels east at $30\,\text{m/s}$, Car B travels west at $20\,\text{m/s}$. They are initially $750\,\text{m}$ apart. How much time will pass before they meet?
questions.explanation: Since they move toward each other, their relative speed is $30 + 20 = 50\,\text{m/s}$. Time to meet $= \text{distance} / \text{relative speed} = 750/50 = 15\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A $12\,\text{kg}$ block is pulled by a horizontal force of $60\,\text{N}$ on a frictionless horizontal surface. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Applying Newton's second law, $F = ma$, we have $a = F/m = 60/12 = 5\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $7\,\text{kg}$ box is pushed with a horizontal force of $56\,\text{N}$. A frictional force of $14\,\text{N}$ opposes the motion. What is the acceleration of the box?
questions.explanation: The net force on the box is $F_{\text{net}} = 56 - 14 = 42\,\text{N}$. Using $F_{\text{net}} = ma$, we find $a = 42/7 = 6\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $5\,\text{kg}$ object moves at constant velocity on a horizontal surface with an applied force of $15\,\text{N}$. What is the frictional force acting on the object?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity implies zero net force. Therefore, the frictional force must exactly balance the applied force, so friction $= 15\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $25\,\text{kg}$ block rests on a frictionless incline of $53^\circ$. What is the component of its weight parallel to the incline? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$, $\sin 53^\circ \approx 0.8$)
questions.explanation: The weight is $mg = 250\,\text{N}$. The component parallel to the incline is $F_{\parallel} = mg\sin\theta = 250 \times 0.8 = 200\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $10\,\text{kg}$ block is on a $45^\circ$ incline with coefficient of friction $\mu = 0.3$. What is the frictional force acting on the block? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: The normal force is $N = mg\cos\theta = 100 \cos 45^\circ \approx 100(0.7071) = 70.71\,\text{N}$. The frictional force is $f = \mu N = 0.3 \times 70.71 \approx 21.2\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: In an Atwood machine, masses of $6\,\text{kg}$ and $9\,\text{kg}$ are connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley. What is the acceleration of the system? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: The net driving force is the weight difference: $F_{\text{net}} = (9-6)g = 3 \times 10 = 30\,\text{N}$. The total mass being accelerated is $m_{\text{total}} = 6 + 9 = 15\,\text{kg}$. Thus $a = F_{\text{net}} / m_{\text{total}} = 30/15 = 2\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $4\,\text{kg}$ mass hangs from a string and accelerates upward at $5\,\text{m/s}^2$. What is the tension in the string? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Applying Newton's second law: $T - mg = ma$. Solving for tension gives $T = m(g + a) = 4(10 + 5) = 4(15) = 60\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: An $80\,\text{N}$ weight is suspended by two identical strings, each making an angle of $30^\circ$ with the vertical. What is the tension in each string?
questions.explanation: From vertical force equilibrium: $2T\cos30^\circ = 80$. Since $\cos30^\circ \approx 0.866$, we have $2T(0.866) = 80 \Rightarrow T = 80/(2 \times 0.866) \approx 46.2\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: Three forces act on an object in equilibrium: $8\,\text{N}$ east, $6\,\text{N}$ north, and an unknown force $\vec{F}$. What is $\vec{F}$?
questions.explanation: The resultant of the $8\,\text{N}$ east and $6\,\text{N}$ north forces is $10\,\text{N}$ directed northeast (by Pythagorean theorem). For equilibrium, $\vec{F}$ must be equal in magnitude and opposite in direction, so $\vec{F} = 10\,\text{N}$ directed southwest.

questions.question: An object moves in a circle of radius $8\,\text{m}$ with constant speed $16\,\text{m/s}$. What is its centripetal acceleration?
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration is given by $a_c = v^2/r = (16)^2 / 8 = 256/8 = 32\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: An object completes $6$ revolutions in $3$ seconds on a circular path. What is its angular velocity?
questions.explanation: Angular displacement $\theta = 6 \times 2\pi = 12\pi$ radians. Angular velocity $\omega = \theta/t = 12\pi/3 = 4\pi\,\text{rad/s}$.

questions.question: A $5\,\text{kg}$ mass is whirled in a vertical circle of radius $3\,\text{m}$. At the bottom of the circle, its speed is $9\,\text{m/s}$. What is the tension in the string? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At the bottom, the net inward force (centripetal force) is $T - mg = mv^2/r$. Thus $T = mg + mv^2/r = 5(10) + 5(81)/3 = 50 + 405/3 = 50 + 135 = 185\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: What is the minimum speed at the top of a vertical circle of radius $10\,\text{m}$ for a mass to just complete the circle without the string going slack? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At the top, the minimum speed occurs when tension is zero, so weight alone provides centripetal force: $mg = mv^2/r$. Solving gives $v = \sqrt{gr} = \sqrt{10 \times 10} = \sqrt{100} = 10\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $6\,\text{kg}$ mass is whirled in a horizontal circle of radius $3\,\text{m}$ at a speed of $9\,\text{m/s}$. What is the tension in the string?
questions.explanation: In horizontal circular motion, tension provides the centripetal force: $T = mv^2/r = 6 \times (9)^2 / 3 = 6 \times 81 / 3 = 486/3 = 162\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $2000\,\text{kg}$ rounds a flat curve of radius $100\,\text{m}$ at $20\,\text{m/s}$. What frictional force provides the centripetal force?
questions.explanation: The centripetal force required is $F = mv^2/r = 2000 \times (20)^2 / 100 = 2000 \times 400 / 100 = 2000 \times 4 = 8000\,\text{N}$. This force is provided by friction.

questions.question: Two masses, $400\,\text{kg}$ and $600\,\text{kg}$, are $10\,\text{m}$ apart. What is the gravitational force between them in terms of the gravitational constant $G$?
questions.explanation: Using Newton's law of gravitation: $F = G m_1 m_2 / r^2 = G(400)(600) / (10)^2 = G(240000) / 100 = 2400G$.

questions.question: If the distance between two masses is tripled, what happens to the gravitational force between them?
questions.explanation: Gravitational force follows an inverse square law: $F \propto 1/r^2$. If $r$ becomes $3r$, then $F$ becomes $1/(3)^2 = 1/9$ of its original value.

questions.question: A box is pushed $15\,\text{m}$ along a horizontal surface with a constant force of $200\,\text{N}$. A frictional force of $60\,\text{N}$ opposes the motion. What is the net work done on the box?
questions.explanation: The net force on the box is $F_{\text{net}} = 200 - 60 = 140\,\text{N}$. Net work $= F_{\text{net}} \times d = 140 \times 15 = 2100\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A $6\,\text{kg}$ object initially at rest is acted upon by a net force of $30\,\text{N}$ over a distance of $24\,\text{m}$. What is its final speed?
questions.explanation: The work done on the object equals its change in kinetic energy: $W = Fd = 30 \times 24 = 720\,\text{J} = \Delta KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$. Solving: $720 = \frac{1}{2}(6)v^2 \Rightarrow 720 = 3v^2 \Rightarrow v^2 = 240 \Rightarrow v = \sqrt{240} \approx 15.49\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $1200\,\text{kg}$ car slows from $25\,\text{m/s}$ to $5\,\text{m/s}$. What is the work done by the brakes?
questions.explanation: The work done equals the change in kinetic energy: $W = \Delta KE = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f^2 - v_i^2) = \frac{1}{2}(1200)(5^2 - 25^2) = 600(25 - 625) = 600(-600) = -360,000\,\text{J} = -360\,\text{kJ}$.

questions.question: A $4\,\text{kg}$ object falls from a height of $20\,\text{m}$. What is its kinetic energy just before impact with the ground? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: By conservation of mechanical energy, the potential energy lost equals kinetic energy gained: $KE = mgh = 4 \times 10 \times 20 = 800\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A ball is dropped from a height of $40\,\text{m}$ and bounces back to a height of $16\,\text{m}$. What percentage of its mechanical energy was lost during the impact?
questions.explanation: Initial potential energy is proportional to height $40\,\text{m}$, final potential energy is proportional to height $16\,\text{m}$. Energy lost $= 40 - 16 = 24$ units. Percentage lost $= 24/40 = 0.6 = 60\%$.

questions.question: A motor lifts a $100\,\text{kg}$ mass vertically at a constant speed of $4\,\text{m/s}$. What power does the motor deliver? (Take $g = 10\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At constant speed, the motor's force equals the weight: $F = mg = 1000\,\text{N}$. Power is $P = Fv = 1000 \times 4 = 4000\,\text{W}$.

questions.question: A constant force of $150\,\text{N}$ acts on an object moving at $8\,\text{m/s}$ in the direction of the force. What power is being delivered to the object?
questions.explanation: Power is given by $P = Fv$ when force and velocity are in the same direction. Thus $P = 150 \times 8 = 1200\,\text{W}$.

questions.question: A spring with spring constant $k = 200\,\text{N/m}$ is stretched by $0.15\,\text{m}$. What is the elastic potential energy stored in the spring?
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy is $E = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = \frac{1}{2} \times 200 \times (0.15)^2 = 100 \times 0.0225 = 2.25\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A wire of original length $4\,\text{m}$ extends by $8\,\text{mm}$ under tension. What is the strain in the wire?
questions.explanation: Strain is defined as the fractional change in length: $\text{strain} = \Delta L / L$. Converting $8\,\text{mm} = 0.008\,\text{m}$, we get $\text{strain} = 0.008 / 4 = 0.002$.

questions.question: In an elastic collision, a $3\,\text{kg}$ ball moving at $12\,\text{m/s}$ strikes a stationary $5\,\text{kg}$ ball head-on. What is the velocity of the $3\,\text{kg}$ ball after the collision?
questions.explanation: For an elastic collision, the final velocity of mass $m_1$ is $v_{1f} = \frac{m_1 - m_2}{m_1 + m_2} \times v_{1i} = \frac{3 - 5}{3 + 5} \times 12 = \frac{-2}{8} \times 12 = -3\,\text{m/s}$. The negative sign indicates motion in the opposite direction.

questions.question: In a perfectly inelastic collision, a $4\,\text{kg}$ object moving at $15\,\text{m/s}$ strikes a stationary $6\,\text{kg}$ object and they stick together. What is their final speed?
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 = (m_1 + m_2)v_f$. Substituting: $4 \times 15 + 6 \times 0 = (4 + 6)v_f \Rightarrow 60 = 10v_f \Rightarrow v_f = 60/10 = 6\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $15\,\text{kg}$ bomb at rest explodes into two pieces: $5\,\text{kg}$ and $10\,\text{kg}$. If the $5\,\text{kg}$ piece moves at $12\,\text{m/s}$, what is the velocity of the $10\,\text{kg}$ piece?
questions.explanation: By conservation of momentum, the total momentum before the explosion is zero. Thus $0 = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2$. Solving for $v_2$: $v_2 = -(m_1v_1)/m_2 = -(5 \times 12)/10 = -60/10 = -6\,\text{m/s}$, which means $6\,\text{m/s}$ in the opposite direction.

questions.question: Three resistors of resistances $2\,\Omega$, $4\,\Omega$, and $6\,\Omega$ are connected in series to a $24\,\text{V}$ battery. What is the current in the circuit?
questions.explanation: The total resistance in series is $R_{\text{total}} = 2 + 4 + 6 = 12\,\Omega$. Using Ohm's law, $I = V/R_{\text{total}} = 24/12 = 2\,\text{A}$.

questions.question: Three $8\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in series. If the current in the circuit is $1.5\,\text{A}$, what is the total voltage across the combination?
questions.explanation: The total resistance is $R_{\text{total}} = 8 + 8 + 8 = 24\,\Omega$. Using Ohm's law, $V = IR_{\text{total}} = 1.5 \times 24 = 36\,\text{V}$.

questions.question: Three $12\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in parallel. What is the equivalent resistance?
questions.explanation: For identical resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is $R_{\text{eq}} = R/n = 12/3 = 4\,\Omega$.

questions.question: A $5\,\Omega$ resistor and a $20\,\Omega$ resistor are connected in parallel to a $30\,\text{V}$ battery. What is the total current drawn from the battery?
questions.explanation: The equivalent resistance of the parallel combination is $R_{\text{eq}} = (5 \times 20)/(5 + 20) = 100/25 = 4\,\Omega$. Using Ohm's law, $I_{\text{total}} = V/R_{\text{eq}} = 30/4 = 7.5\,\text{A}$.

questions.question: Two $8\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in parallel. This combination is connected in series with a $5\,\Omega$ resistor. What is the total resistance of the circuit?
questions.explanation: For the two $8\,\Omega$ resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is $R_{\text{parallel}} = (8 \times 8)/(8 + 8) = 64/16 = 4\,\Omega$. Adding the series $5\,\Omega$ resistor gives $R_{\text{total}} = 4 + 5 = 9\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $10\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in parallel. This combination is connected in series with a $5\,\Omega$ resistor. The circuit is connected to a $30\,\text{V}$ battery. What is the total current drawn from the battery?
questions.explanation: For the two $10\,\Omega$ resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is $R_{\text{parallel}} = (10 \times 10)/(10 + 10) = 100/20 = 5\,\Omega$. Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 5 + 5 = 10\,\Omega$. Current $I = V/R_{\text{total}} = 30/10 = 3\,\text{A}$.

questions.question: A wave has a frequency of $150\,\text{Hz}$ and a speed of $450\,\text{m/s}$. What is its wavelength?
questions.explanation: The wave equation is $v = f\lambda$, so $\lambda = v/f = 450/150 = 3\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: In a transverse wave, the distance from a crest to the adjacent trough is $1.5\,\text{m}$. What is the wavelength?
questions.explanation: The distance from a crest to the next trough is half a wavelength. Therefore, $\lambda/2 = 1.5\,\text{m}$, so $\lambda = 2 \times 1.5 = 3\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A sound wave has a frequency of $800\,\text{Hz}$ and travels at $320\,\text{m/s}$. What is its wavelength?
questions.explanation: Using $v = f\lambda$, we find $\lambda = v/f = 320/800 = 0.4\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: Two sound waves of the same frequency interfere. The path difference between them is $1.5\lambda$. What type of interference occurs?
questions.explanation: Destructive interference occurs when the path difference is an odd multiple of half wavelengths. Here $1.5\lambda = \frac{3}{2}\lambda$ fits this pattern, so destructive interference occurs.

questions.question: A sound source emits a frequency of $600\,\text{Hz}$ and approaches a stationary observer at $30\,\text{m/s}$. The speed of sound is $330\,\text{m/s}$. What frequency does the observer hear?
questions.explanation: Using the Doppler effect formula for a moving source approaching a stationary observer: $f' = f \left( \frac{v}{v - v_s} \right) = 600 \left( \frac{330}{330 - 30} \right) = 600 \left( \frac{330}{300} \right) = 600 \times 1.1 = 660\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: An open pipe has a length of $1\,\text{m}$. The speed of sound in air is $340\,\text{m/s}$. What is the fundamental frequency of the pipe?
questions.explanation: For an open pipe, the fundamental wavelength is $\lambda = 2L = 2 \times 1 = 2\,\text{m}$. The fundamental frequency is $f = v/\lambda = 340/2 = 170\,\text{Hz}$.
